title: CULT OF THE DEAD COW Sought In Obscenity Case
historical_context: This article discusses the legal challenges surrounding obscenity laws and the implications for internet censorship during the mid-1990s, a time when the internet was becoming more mainstream.
target_audience: Hackers, security professionals, internet freedom advocates.
short_summary: The article explores a legal case in Memphis involving obscenity charges against a couple, highlighting the involvement of the notorious hacking group 'Cult of the Dead Cow' in producing obscene material. It critiques the potential impact of censorship on internet freedom.
summary:
In this article, Weasel Boy and Lizard delve into a Memphis obscenity case that has drawn attention to the role of the 'Cult of the Dead Cow' in producing graphic and disturbing content online. The prosecutors are struggling to identify the members of this elusive group, which has been linked to over 300 obscene files on the internet. The case raises significant questions about the nature of internet distribution and the challenges of policing online content, especially when anonymity is a key feature of hacker culture. The authors provide a snapshot of the legal landscape, emphasizing the difficulties faced by law enforcement in addressing obscenity in the digital age.

Lizard takes a strong stance against internet censorship, arguing that proposed laws would cripple American ISPs and stifle the free exchange of information. He warns that the push for stricter regulations is driven by a desire for control rather than genuine concern for public welfare. The article serves as a rallying cry for those who value internet freedom, urging readers to resist censorship efforts by any means necessary. It reflects the broader tensions of the time, as the internet was rapidly evolving and becoming a battleground for issues of free speech and regulation.
